awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Language, race, and Identity among ethnically diverse youths in Miami
awd_abstract_narration:
The relatively recent migration of Haitians to South Florida has rapidly changed the demographics of Miami Dade County's majority Black neighborhoods. This has caused tensions between the newly arrived Haitian ethnic group and the historically established African Americans. Residents of both ethnicities note that these tensions begin in middle school. This longitudinal study follows a set of new sixth grade students through their first year at a middle school. These participants will need to learn the middle school community's expectations of acceptable racial and ethnic interactions and they will need to join or create social groups that either uphold or abandon these social expectations. As they are adapting to these social expectations, they will be subtly changing their speech to show solidarity with their own social groups and to create social distance from other groups. The life stage of these middle school participants is incredibly important for their own growth into adolescent and adult members of their communities which, in turn, is important for the further development of the societies to which they belong. This work will advance the scientific understanding of how youths learn social expectations and apply that knowledge to their own linguistic behaviors. It will also expand research on language variation by applying previous knowledge to understudied, diverse social groups. This study's broader impacts include publicly available recordings of youth speech, a workshop on language variation and ethnic bullying for teachers and administration in the middle school, and the dissemination of the sociolinguistic knowledge to the general public via press releases.  

The CoPI, a doctoral student at the Ohio State University, will conduct ethnographic fieldwork in a Miami middle school concentrating the data collection and analysis on a set of 20 to 30 sixth grade students belonging to the same homeroom. This project focuses on the ethnic make-up of the social groups of African and Haitian American students and quantifies the changes in speech that these new students experience as they become enmeshed into the middle school's particular social environment. Two dependent linguistic variables will be analyzed for this project: 3rd person singular verbal-s absence and prosodic rhythm. 3rd person singular verbal-s will be coded as present or absent for each present tense, present reference phrase. A number of factors that influence -s usage, such as verb type and sentence structure, will also be coded. Prosodic rhythm will be measured using a host of established rhythm measures (PVI, %V, ∆C, and varcoC). These two linguistic variables have been shown to vary because of bilingualism and social identity; as a result, this project has two primary independent variables: language background and social network. This project employs a mixed methodological approach that is becoming more common in linguistic anthropological and sociolinguistic work. It includes diverse data collection methods: participant observation, audio-recorded linguistic and ethnographic interviews, network analysis, and a language background questionnaire. The data analysis includes both statistical analysis and qualitative coding, which adds depth to the results. The findings of this study will widen the sociolinguistic knowledge of Miami, Black communities, and the US-at-large.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Nandi Sims completed her dissertation 'Race, ethnicity, interests, and linguistic variation at a primarily Black Miami middle school' with the support of this Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. This project aimed to describe the social structures and language variation prevalent at a South Florida middle school in light of the historical prevalence of migration to the region and attitudes surrounding race and ethnicity held by adults in these communities. While the COVID-19 pandemic changed the nature of the project from its original form, Dr. Sims' findings still have important implications for studies of language variation, language contact, and youth speech.

The social structures at this middle school related directly to global ideologies surrounding race and ethnicity. The primary social splits were along racial, ethnic, and social lines. Overall, the students were unable to describe their racial, ethnic, and social identities with depth, but their behaviors and choice of friendships showed an unspoken knowledge of social expectations. The most important social split at the middle school was between the phenotypically and culturally defined 'Black' and 'Hispanic' groups. Within the Black group, students had a secondary split between students who were perceived as 'American' and students who were perceived as 'Haitian'. This split mirrored tensions between Haitian and African Americans discussed by adults in the community but was not strongly tied to heritage as it was to the participation in culturally salient differences such as accessories, primary language, and behavior. Finally, the students split between groups like those found at any US secondary school for example the 'nerd,' 'popular,' and 'bad' kids.

For the linguistic analysis, she examined a total of 8 variables, each of which had previously been shown to differ within English varieties due to factors like regional dialect, identity, and bilingualism (i.e., present tense copula; third-singular, plural, and possessive -s; /ae, a, o, ai/). The two primary reasons for linguistic variation were new dialect formation and anti-Black linguistic ideologies.  The vocalic variables differed significantly between students, but this variation was not due to the school's social structure or the individual student's language backgrounds as we originally hypothesized. This variation was likely due to the decades of language contact between languages like English, Spanish, and Haitian Creole that has defined the region and the lack of a local standard to dictate proper use of these variants. Features strongly associated with African American Language (e.g., PRIZE-PRY weakening; variable copula absence; etc.) were specifically controlled by many of the students and were often discussed using anti-African American terms (e.g., ghetto, thug). The salience of this variation demonstrated the often-overwhelming pervasiveness of anti-Blackness in US society and within even primarily-Black communities.

This dissertation adds to theory in fields like sociology, social psychology, and anthropology and linguistic subfields like language acquisition, sociolinguistics, and contact linguistics. The students' primary focus on race in both their social structures and linguistic choices supports past work regarding race in the US particularly with regards to the Black/white binary and the hegemonic nature of whiteness. The students' lack of attention to factors like ethnic heritage, especially when compared to ethnic tensions present within the adult population, in some ways demonstrates the effects of assimilation and in other ways shows how categories can be redefined over time to reflect community changes. The lack of influence from students' home languages on their speech muddies hypotheses in contact linguistics that have suggested some types of linguistic transfer and interference are virtually unavoidable.  Lastly, the linguistic description provided by this dissertation adds depth to the plethora of work on African American Language particularly with regards to the effects of contact on the variety's vowel space and the uptake of the variety by those without African American heritage. This list of contributions is far from exhaustive, however it provides just a small example of the ways Dr. Sims' dissertation interacts with work in an interdisciplinary academic space.
